 This has been a learning experience for me as well. I wasn't too familiar with the use of bots in such forums until this thread. I had seen single post posters before but had simply assumed that they were people who liked spouting their opinion with no interest in discussion. It certainly makes sense that such people can distribute their opinion far more widely with bots than by painstakingly sending out each individual post. 
 
 As Iuris mentioned in the last post, I can imagine that it would be very difficult to reliably weed out bots. I suppose that, after a pattern is established, then one could more easily recognize a bot and then the administrator could do a test to verify before blocking the bot (example, asking the poster to actually reply to a post or sending him/her/it a message to respond to). Outside of such blocking of established bots, there are mechanisms to limit their use. In this forum, I believe that there was supposed to be a rule that a new poster had to first take part in a few existing threads before starting his/her own thread. For some unknown reason, this rule seems to have been ignored in the case of Momento.
